file_content.text: We'll be dropping out of hyperspace shortly. Be ready to launch that assault shuttle when we arrive at Maelstrom Prison.
Cut your escape awfully close. Grand Moff Kilran destroyed the fortress just moments after you left.
We suffered heavy losses at Taral Five: the Dantooine, the Serroco... more starfighters than I care to count.
But there's no time to mourn the dead. We must strike the Empire's prison before the enemy bolsters its defense.
Down on Taral Five, your Jedi friend sent us warnings. We couldn't see her, but it was definitely her voice.
The dead Jedi contacted us.
Extraordinary. Your team has a powerful ally. The Force is with you.
Down on Taral Five, your Jedi friend sent warnings. She didn't appear, but it was definitely her voice.
The dead Jedi contacted me.
Good. She's a powerful ally, and her counsel is useful--always listen.
You aren't a Force user. That's extraordinary--and wonderful. Heed her advice.
What defenses are protecting the prison? How hard will it be to crack into?
How tough will this be?
The prison's location is its primary defense. Difficult to attack what you can't find. More than that, we don't know.
Grand Moff Kilran has to know what we're up to. His fleet is probably on its way there.
We need reinforcements.
All the more reason to move quickly while we have one advantage he doesn't: the latest coordinates through the nebula.
My technicians have plugged the Gree computer into the Telos's hyperdrive. We're already calculating a safe route to Maelstrom Prison.
When we arrive, I need my best people leading the raid. You're the Jedi prisoner's only hope of escaping alive.
I'll carve open every blast door in the prison by hand, if that's what it takes.
You can count on me, Master.
Even with a lightsaber, that might be time consuming. I recommend searching for the keys, first.
The Force has brought us together. I will see this through, wherever it leads.
I feel the pull of destiny.
Let the Force be your guide--but keep your eyes open, too.
Havoc Squad gets the job done every time, sir.
Understood, Admiral.
I've asked too much of you, young one. Too much of everyone.
If there's one thing I'm known for, it's daring rescues. That, and impeccable timing. Snappy comebacks are a close third....
Of course I am.
Heh... the spirit of youth. Hard to believe it's been two-hundred years since I was your age....
Do we have a plan to free the rest of the captives? We're not just leaving them there, are we?
What about other prisoners?
The facility was specifically built for the Jedi prisoner. The good news is, you should only have to break open one cell.
It would be helpful to know who I'm rescuing.
Do we even know his name?
I asked my source the same thing. She said revealing too much could jeopardize his rescue. You'll know everything before I do.
This mission will cost more lives before it's done, but it's a necessary sacrifice. The Jedi prisoner can end this war--save countless worlds.
We'll be jumping to hyperspace soon. Head for the shuttle bays. Be ready to launch on my signal. May the Force be with you.
The Imperial shuttle will take you to Taral Five--but I will be in constant communication. Now go....
Welcome, friends. You're even more impressive in person. Forgive me for not shaking hands, but I forgot my hover seat today. Heh....
Welcome, my friend. I appreciate you coming all this way. Oh, do forgive me for not shaking hands. My hospitality exceeds my reach, heh....
Before we begin, I'll ask that you keep an open mind to what you're about to hear. The source of my information is... unconventional.
A Jedi is prepared to accept help from any source.
That doesn't bother me.
Such wisdom in one so young. Master Satele's faith is well placed.
I get the feeling this isn't a standard military operation.
Now you're intriguing me.
Your instincts are one of the many reasons you were summoned for this mission.
A good source of intel only needs to be reliable.
Fine--but is it trustworthy?
I assure you, the information couldn't be from a more legitimate origin.
You should see the sources I usually rely on. They redefine "disreputable."
Not a problem.
Despite its unusual nature, my source is of the highest integrity.
I'm already worried.
"Unconventional" does not mean "unreliable." Let go of your prejudices.
You're wasting my time.
Patience, young one. Understanding comes only to a clear mind.
I will share with all of you what I have seen. Come--stand together.
As a Jedi, you are already attuned to the Force. But you must deepen your connection to see as I do.
You are not a Jedi, but you can still experience the Force's mysteries--with my help.
Concentrate with me. Focus your mind. Feel the Force around us. Hear its echoes....
Follow Oteg's lead. This is important.
Everyone work together.
[You concentrate with Master Oteg, opening your mind.]
[Remain silent]
Yes... the Force is with us....
Am I listening for anything particular?
What will I hear?
A voice that seeks to be heard. It was silenced long ago, but now it returns....
I didn't come here to stand in a circle and chant nonsense.
This is ridiculous.
Control your emotions. Release your fear. Then, you will see....
She is here... a Jedi without physical form. Her body is long dead, but her wisdom--her essence--lives on.
My Master died, but his voice still speaks to me.
I've experienced this before.
One Jedi persisting beyond death is almost unheard-of. But two? These are strange, dark times indeed.
I encountered a fallen Jedi who did this--and a Sith whose will lived on long after death. He could possess another living being.
I've experienced this before.
Sith who persist beyond death are aberrations. Expressions of greed and pride. For a pure Jedi to do this... something terrible has happened.
When you said your source was unconventional, I wasn't picturing a... whatever that is.
I wasn't expecting that.
Most Jedi go their entire lives without experiencing anything like this. You are special.
What I really need are the winners of the next major swoop circuit. She have those?
I'm all ears.
Put aside worldly concerns. Open your heart as well as your mind. Jedi who persist beyond death have suffered greatly.
The dead shouldn't be able to speak, much less appear.
How can that be?
And yet, she does. Her death must have been a terrible thing.
The dead don't speak. I should know--I've killed plenty of people.
This is impossible.
Do not deny what your feelings tell you is true. She is real--and she needs our help.
The darkness will consume all it touches. Stars will burn black, ashes raining on lifeless worlds. Everything ends.
The prisoner holds the darkness at bay, lost inside it for three-hundred years. His strength will fail. Then, he will become the darkness.
Our team will free your friend, no matter what it takes. That's a promise.
We will save this prisoner.
I promise the prisoner will be freed, no matter what it takes.
I will save this prisoner.
This prisoner has been fighting the Empire for centuries? How is he still alive?
Three-hundred years?
No more riddles. If you want help, start speaking Basic.
Stop babbling and make sense.
The bond weakens, my friend. I'll take things from here....
She's told me many things. Revealed the existence of an Imperial prison in the constantly shifting Maelstrom Nebula--and a way to get there.
The only way to navigate the Maelstrom is using a Gree computer hidden at an Imperial fortress. We need that computer to free the Jedi prisoner.
Consider it done.
What's a "Gree," and how are its computers so special?
"Gree"?
Gree are an ancient civilization, rarely seen anymore. How the Empire obtained their technology is a mystery.
Imperial fortresses are bad.
I would not throw you into the fire unless I had no other option.
The fortress we're invading is on the planet Taral Five. Enemy territory, protected by Imperial warships. Too many to fight.
But we have a captured Imperial shuttle that can sneak past the sentries. It's waiting for you in the hangar.
You can fill me in on the rest while we travel. There's no time to waste.
Then let's get started.
No offense, but I'd feel a lot more comfortable invading Imperial space in my own starship.
I'd rather take my own ship.
You wouldn't make it past the first Imperial cruiser. This is the only way.
You're a powerful Jedi Master. Shouldn't you be part of this?
Aren't you coming with me?
My strength is strategy, not fighting. I would simply be underfoot, heh....
Our fleet will hide at the system's edge so I can monitor your mission and guide you. If something goes wrong, we'll come running.
Go to the shuttle, my friends. May the Force be with you.
Now go to the shuttle, my friend--and may the Force be with you.
Everyone work together.
What will I hear?
What will I hear?
